I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed project 
readiness  financing  (PRF)  loan  to  the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Transport 
Connectivity Improvement Preparatory Facility. 
 
2.  Bangladesh  requires  further  development  of  an  optimized  transport  network  with 
strengthened intermodal connections to meet its rapidly growing transport demand. The objective 
of the facility is to support the Government of Bangladesh in advancing the preparation of road 
and railway projects by financing feasibility studies, detailed design, and other preparatory works. 
These projects will improve transport connectivity and facilitate multimodal transport in the country 
and South Asia. 
 
II.  PROJECT READINESS FINANCING 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Bangladesh  economy.  Bangladesh,  with  a  population  of  165  million,  has  been 
experiencing robust annual economic growth of 5% or higher since fiscal year (FY) 2004. 
Bangladesh’s annual economic growth of 7.9% in FY 2018 was the highest among Asian 
countries, and it is forecasted to further grow by 8.1% in FY2019 and 8.0 % in FY2020.1 The 
proportion of population living below the national poverty line decreased from 31.5% in 2010 to 
24.3% in 2016, although this was still the highest proportion among South Asian countries.2 
Foreign trade is a vital engine of the country’s economic growth. Foreign merchandise trade in 
Bangladesh recorded a 480% increase in value from 2000 to 2017.3 This indicates that the 
country has the potential to grow further as a major exporter of labor-intensive products, including 
garments.  Expansion  of  exports  is  expected  to  bring  about  economic  growth,  resulting  in 
increased  incomes  that  will  contribute  to  boosting  domestic  consumption.  In  addition,  the 
proximity of Bangladesh to neighboring Southeast Asia provides the country with good prospects 
of becoming a regional trading hub. 
 
4.  Transport network in Bangladesh. Bangladesh’s transport network consists of roads, 
railways, inland waterways, seaports, and civil aviation. Among these, road is the predominant 
subsector with a modal share of over 70% for passenger traffic and 60% for freight.4 The 
government estimates that national road traffic volume is growing at an average rate of above 
10% per year.5 Rail is considered a safer, more reliable, and environmentally friendly transport 
mode in the country. Rail transport is also steadily increasing in traffic volume for passenger and 
cargo. Chattogram Port, formerly called Chittagong Port, is the national gateway port handling 
more than 90% of the country’s international cargo, and is the busiest container port in the Bay of 
Bengal. It is expected that international container cargo volume will increase to 10.2 million 
twenty-foot equivalent units in 2040.6  
 
 
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2019. Asian Development Outlook 2019 Update: Fostering Growth and Inclusion 
in Asia’s Cities. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2019. Basic Statistics 2019. Manila. 
3  World Trade Organization. Statistics database, time series (accessed 15 April 2019). 
4  Government of Bangladesh, Planning Commission, General Economics Division. 2015. Seventh Five-Year Plan, 
FY2016–FY2020: Accelerating Growth, Empowering Citizens. Dhaka. 
5  Road and Highways Department estimate. 
6  ADB. 2015. Strategic Master Plan for Chittagong Port. Manila. Twenty-foot equivalent units are used to count 
container volume; a 40-foot container box is counted as two twenty-foot equivalent units.

2 
5.  Transport connectivity for an optimized network. Bangladesh’s transport network is a 
fundamental and critical infrastructure that supports the country’s economic activities, including 
international trade. Insufficient transport infrastructure results in increased costs and transport 
time,  reduced  competitiveness  and  efficiency  of  the  economy,  and  impeded  economic 
opportunities. Transport demand is expanding rapidly nationwide because of Bangladesh’s young 
and growing population, and steady economic development. Thus, the government has been 
substantially investing in all subsectors to strengthen Bangladesh’s transport network and support 
the efficient, safe and sustainable movement of people and goods in the country and across the 
region.  
 
6.  Improvements in transport connectivity that will link subsectors are necessary towards an 
integrated  transport  network. Insufficient transport  connectivity  in  the country  has  led to  a 
disproportionate reliance on roads, causing congestion and inconvenience to users. Promoting 
multimodal transport and optimized modal share will alleviate unbalanced transport demands in 
the country. For example, utilizing freight trains and inland waterways for long-haul freight 
transport between Dhaka and Chattogram Port is a potential solution to alleviate the congestion. 
However, this requires adequate transport connectivity with the road network at intermodal 
transshipment facilities such as inland container depots and inland waterway terminals.  
 
7.  Arterial transport corridors. Because of rapidly growing demand, the main road and rail 
corridors  in  Bangladesh  face  severe  capacity  shortages.  Given  that  road  and  railway  are 
fundamental components of an integrated transport network, the alleviation of congestion along 
arterial transport corridors is urgently needed. In tandem with the improvement of transport 
connectivity, arterial transport corridors need to be strengthened through upgrades as well as 
through the construction of bypass roads and connecting roads. 
 
8.  Transport connectivity and intra-subregional trade. Intra-subregional trade in South 
Asia is less active compared with that in other subregions such as the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nations and the European Union.7 The relatively low volume of intra-subregional trade 
among South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) countries is partly attributed to 
insufficient  transport  connectivity,  and  incomplete  transport  network.  Subregional  transport 
corridors, including the SASEC road corridors and the Trans-Asian Railway network, will link 
Bangladesh with neighboring countries through border crossing points and land ports. The 
corridors will provide access to international markets and economic opportunities not only for 
Bangladesh, but also for neighboring countries through Bangladesh. However, international road 
and rail corridors are still being developed, and border crossing points and land ports are still 
physically constrained because of insufficient road and rail connectivity, although the government 
has declared 23 land ports. 
 
9.  Government  strategy.  The  government’s  Seventh  Five-Year  Plan  prioritizes  the 
improvement of the multimodal transport network, utilization of rail in long-haul freight traffic, 
promotion of regional connectivity, and reduction of urban traffic congestion, among others 
(footnote  4).  The  use of  a  long-haul freight  train  between  Dhaka  and  Chattogram  Port  is 
particularly promoted by the government. Bangladesh Railway has established a container freight 
company and plans to expand the container freight yard next to Chattogram Port. Pilot operation 
of an international container train between Bangladesh and India was also conducted in 2018. 
The Bangladesh Land Port Authority has declared 23 land ports as of March 2019, including six 
 
7  Intraregional trade as a share of total trade is 63.9% for the European Union and 22.8% for the Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations, compared to an intra-subregional trade share of 5.0% for South Asia Subregional 
Economic Cooperation (SASEC) countries.

3 
land ports operated by the private sector. ADB is currently discussing with relevant government 
agencies about the ensuing support for land port and border management as another project. 
 
10.  Facility to support project preparation. The preparation of such projects to facilitate 
transport connectivity among different subsectors has lagged behind actual development needs, 
and financial support is needed to advance this. In parallel with the government’s plan to optimize 
the country’s transport network and to strengthen competitiveness of the economy, the PRF will 
support project preparation in the following areas: (i) road and rail connectivity of ports, land ports, 
and border crossing points; (ii) road and rail connectivity of intermodal transshipment facilities, 
including inland container depots and inland container terminals; (iii) strengthening of corridors, 
including bypasses, connected roads, and alternate routes; and (iv) sector-wide improvements, 
including safety, traffic management, and maintenance. Projects will be  selected in line with the 
project  selection  criteria,  including  urgency  of the  needs, viability  for future financing,  and 
development  coordination.8 The  PRF  will  advance  the  preparation  of  ensuing  projects  by 
financing feasibility studies, detailed design, and other preparatory works. 
 
11.  ADB strategy and value addition. The PRF was newly institutionalized as an innovative 
financing modality in 2018  to ensure a high level of implementation readiness. The proposed 
facility meets the strategic objectives of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership 
strategy  for  Bangladesh,  2016–2020,  particularly  by  (i)  easing  infrastructure  constraints  in 
transport and urban development, (ii) creating conditions for greater private sector participation 
to attract investment, and (iii) helping Bangladesh take advantage of its location as a regional 
transport and trade hub.9 ADB’s engagement will complement strategies of other development 
partners by exploring the use of a sector-wide approach and pursuing comprehensive policy 
dialogues with the government. The facility will also expedite the preparation of projects for 
regional cooperation and integration in line with the SASEC Operational Plan, 2016–2025.10 In 
addition, the facility is aligned with the operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 as it will 
contribute to the: (i) development of green and inclusive infrastructure as well as the reduction of 
greenhouse gas emissions in transport; (ii) reducing inequality access to opportunities and 
promoting women’s economic empowerment; and (iii) regional cooperation and integration.11 The 
facility is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 2020–2022.12  
 
B.  Output and Activities 
 
12.   Output:  Feasibility  studies,  detailed  design,  and  other  preparatory  works  for 
ensuing projects completed. All preparatory works will be done to satisfy ADB’s due diligence 
requirements. The facility will assess risks of ensuing projects related to gender, labor, and other 
social issues during the preparation of the feasibility study and detailed design in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and other guidelines, as well as government guidelines 
and regulations. Participation of private sector in ensuing projects will be preliminarily assessed.  
 
13.  Environmental impact assessments or initial environmental examinations, as applicable, 
will  be  prepared  along  with  climate  risk  and  vulnerability  assessments  and  environmental 
management plans for ensuing projects. Similarly, resettlement plans and indigenous people’s

plans will also be prepared for each ensuing project. Consulting firms will conduct all preparatory 
works, while individual consultants will be mobilized for quality assurance to support the executing 
agency in reviewing deliverables by the firms. 
 
C.  Ensuing Projects 
 
14.  Ensuing projects to be prepared under the PRF shall satisfy the project selection criteria 
(footnote 8). The government has developed a list of necessary investments from which ensuing 
projects suitable for future ADB financing will be selected.14  
 
D.  Cost Estimates and Financing Arrangements

Taxes and duties are not financed by the facility. 
 
16.  Consulting services are a major component of the PRF, amounting to $53.7 million 
including taxes and duties. The recurrent cost is $1.3 million, while $2.2 million is allocated for 
financial charges.

19.  The project readiness loan will be repaid according to the loan agreement. However,

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  The list of necessary investments which the PRF will support was prepared according to 
the agreed project selection criteria (footnote 8). Ensuing projects will be selected from the list to 
improve transport connectivity and facilitate multimodal transport. These investments are in line 
with recent government priorities, including subregional cooperation and integration, intermodal 
connection, and strengthening of industries. Most of the required investments (candidate projects) 
are identified in the Seventh Five-Year Plan (footnote 4) or the Railway Sector Master Plan toward 
2030.17 The detailed design will consider climate change impact, gender, environment, and other 
requirements. The application of high-level technology will be explored during implementation. 
Individual consultants will be mobilized to support the executing agencies in reviewing detailed 
design and other preparatory works by consulting firms to assure the quality of outputs, especially 
on high-level and new technology. Consulting services are packaged to bundle multiple candidate 
projects of the same subsector for consistency in preparation of projects and to determine priority 
among them. Such procurement packaging, combined with a selection method that places greater 
weight on the quality of proposals, will aim to achieve value for money. 
 
B.  Governance 
 
23.  The  Roads  and  Highways  Department  (RHD)  and  Bangladesh  Railway  will  be  the 
executing agencies of the facility. Both the RHD and Bangladesh Railway have implemented 
ADB-funded projects and are familiar with ADB’s project financial accounting and disbursement 
procedures. One finance (account) official will be designated in each project implementation unit. 
In addition, the RHD and Bangladesh Railway have participated in workshops to learn good 
practices  of  financial  management  systems.  The  overall  financial  management  capacity  is 
adequate, but given the country risk rating, the project risk is considered moderate. The main 
financial management risks are related to external audit, internal audit, and staffing. If ensuing 
projects prepared under the facility will be implemented by another agency, the agency will 
undergo financial management assessment as well as other due diligence during appraisal of the 
ensuing loans. 
 
24.  The procurement risk of the RHD and Bangladesh Railway is rated moderate, as only the 
consultant recruitment is to be financed under the facility. Procurement of consulting services will 
be conducted in line with the ADB Procurement Policy and the Procurement Regulations for ADB 
Borrowers. Disbursement will follow ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended 
from time to time). The advance fund and the statement of expenditure procedures will be applied 
to disbursements for national individual consultants. 
 
25.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, the RHD, and Bangladesh Railway. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 15). 
 
C.  Safeguards 
 
26.  Since the proposed activities consist of consulting services only, the facility has not been 
categorized  per  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  facility  will  support  the

development of environmentally and socially viable ensuing projects. Impact18 of ensuing projects 
on environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples will be scrutinized.19 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
27.  The  government,  the  RHD,  and  Bangladesh  Railway  have  assured  ADB  that  PRF 
implementation  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
28.  I am satisfied that the proposed project readiness financing loan would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the loan of $42,000,000 to the People’s Republic of Bangladesh for the Transport 
Connectivity  Improvement  Preparatory  Facility,  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  in 
concessional terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 2% per year during the grace period 
and thereafter; for a term of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms 
and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement 
presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
